title: London's junior stock market Aim loses another nominated adviser
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Jul 6, 2015, 15:22 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 8 mins London's junior stock market Aim loses another nominated adviser By Marion Dakers | Telegraph – 18 minutes ago 0.00 
Execution Noble could reapply to advise Aim firms at a later date 
London’s Alternative Investment Market has lost another of its corporate advisers, at least temporarily, as the pool of City firms working with the junior market continues to shrink. 
Execution Noble, which became part of the Portuguese group Espirito Santo in 2010, has asked for its status as a nominated adviser (nomad) to be removed with immediate effect. 
The move is thought to be linked to the imminent takeover of Banco Espirito Santo de Investimento, the nomad’s parent entity, by Haitong Securities of China. 
Execution Noble is free to reapply for nomad status with the stock market once the Haitong deal completes. However, it no longer has any nomad clients after the last one, Forum Energy (LSE: FEP.L - news ) , was taken private by Philex Petroleum. Forum's shares were cancelled from Aim on June 25. 
Another client, NAHL Group (LSE: NAH.L - news ) , parted ways in May as Investec (LSE: INVP.L - news ) became its sole broker. 
There are now 39 nomads registered with the London Stock Exchange Group, which runs Aim. Three of these advisers PwC, HSBC, Deloitte have no current nomad clients, while several large investment banks including Goldman Sachs (NYSE: GS-PB - news ) and Bank of America Merrill Lynch have recently withdrawn their services from the junior stock market. 
Marcus Stuttard, the head of Aim, recently said the drop-off in advisers had cleared out “a long tail of inactive nomads”. 
Aim is the listing venue for more than a thousand small-cap and fast-growing companies. The market has helped firms to raise £90bn since its inception 20 years ago, although it has faced criticism for price growth that has lagged behind other global markets.
